body.title: Digital Marketing Excellence
body.p: Now in its sixth edition, the hugely popular Digital Marketing Excellence is a practical guide to creating and executing integrated digital marketing plans, combining established approaches to marketing planning with the creative use of new digital models and digital tools.
Written by two highly experienced digital marketing consultants, the book shows you how to:

sec.title: Digital Marketing In Context
sec.p: Digital Marketing = Marketing

Digital marketing doesn’t happen in isolation; indeed many have said that, today, digital marketing is marketing because of the dramatic growth inadoption of digital devices, digital communications and E-commerce sales we have experienced over the last 30 years. With the majority of business to consumer (B2C) and business to business (B2B) purchases involving digital touchpoints, we believe it’s essential that businesses invest in dedicated resources, plan-ning and optimization for digital marketing. It’s also essential for marketers to develop specific digital marketing skills.

In Chapter 1 we highlight the vital role of digital marketing within marketing and how it relates to the broader context of global challenges. We start by highlighting the growth in Purpose-Driven Marketing along with the emergence of stakeholder capitalism (and stakeholder marketing). We introduce the Virtuous Circle of Insights-Driven Marketing to show how businesses can compete if they adopt the right mindset. This chapter explains digital marketing jargon to clarify key digital marketing concepts from lifecycle marketing to digital transformation and the “post-digital world”. Finally, we introduce PR Smith’s SOSTAC® Planning methodology explaining how you can create a more strategic approach to creating and integrating digital plans (which is detailed in Chapter 10) to deliver the 5S benefits of digital marketing.

p.bold: Why does digital marketing demand dedicated resources and plans?M

sec.p: Digital marketing should be integrated with traditional marketing since it needs to support the same goals and most customers will experience both. However, digital marketing is complex and requires careful planning, analysis and implementation to be effective. That’s the reason behind the popularity of Digital Marketing Excellence: Planning, Optimizing, Automating and Integrating Online Marketing. Now in its sixth edition, it has been used as a core text on many digital marketing diplomas and university modules because it is dedicated to digital marketing and explains how marketing and digital goals and strategy must work together.

Yet, some say we are in a post-digital world, so we must ask you one simple question, which others may ask you: “why bother?” Why bother with digital marketing? It’s so fast changing, sometimes complicated and often confusing, that we forget the only reason why we build a website, an app, a bot, a product, a service, an experience or evena business. The answer is “to help customersbetter than competitors.” Plus, to gain awareness, encourage purchase and deliver quality customercare, it’s essential to be visible online to complete. Keep this close to your heart as you progress through your career. Sometimes technology’s functional potential is so exciting that we forget why we are doing it in the first place. . . “to help customers” or “to help stakeholders” (like the communities we live in andthe planet we live on). The ongoing popularity of digital transformation programmes amongst larger businesses 30 years plus since the invention of the web shows that businesses have found it challenging to adapt to the speed of change and still need to refinetheir approaches to managing and integrating. If we were truly in a post-digital world there would be noneed for transformation programmes.

p.bold: The most exciting time to work in marketing?

sec.p: There is no doubt that this is the most exciting time to work in marketing as what we can now do withdigital techniques like Artificial Intelligence (AI)and Virtual Reality (VR) would have been considered magic 20 years ago. We will see in Chapter 2 that there are literally thousands of marketing technology (MarTech) options to help us automate and personalize customer communications and capture and analyse data. But we have to select the best options, considerthe integration of data and question the return on investment of using these tools. Some of the many MarTech choices are shown in Figure 1.1, which summarizes how 30 different categories of marketing softwarearound the edge of the wheel can support marketersinachieving their customer lifecycle goals and KPIsshown at the centre of the wheel. For each of the 30categories we have selected five options that are someof the most widely used tools with those towardsthe edge of the wheel typically offering low-costor free options, with more sophisticated, enterpriseversionstowards the centre of the wheel. At the end of Chapter 3, we show how to simplify more complex MarTech stacks into a MarTech spine.

fig.label: FIGURE 1.1
fig.caption: The MarTech Wheel - a summary of marketing technologies to support lifecycle marketing activities.

sec.p: Throughout the book we will explore all the majortechnology developments in marketing.As marketers become more data-driven and insights-driven and more analytical, we can measure,quantify and calculate thereturn on investment (ROI) on just about everything we do.This opens the boardroom door wide for marketers to step in and justify why they need more resources to integrate their digital marketing to align with marketing goals.

Increasing use of MarTech and AI should also loosen up our thinking and encourages more room for creative thinking and more room for insight-driven decisions. We also have the challenge of keeping up-to-date practices and selecting the best options from themarketing techniques available from the digital platforms like the search engines and social networks.

The COVID pandemic has affected us all and significantly changed the lives of hundreds of millions of people directly and indirectly. COVID has prompted us all to reflect on our neigh-bours locally and globally. As marketers and business people, we are reviewing how we operate and work. The pandemic has prompted the use of remote working, virtual meeting and events that need to be supported by digital marketing activities. Within B2B sectors marketing, pro-fessional development has been supported by huge increases in engagement as suggested by the B2B webinar platform BrightTALK (Figure 1.2).

It’s positive that the rich content available through digital platforms can support professional development goals as summarized by BrightTALK (2021) as we hope to support readers through this book and its online resources. Top-rated reasons for using these platforms for professional development were:

list.list-item: To keep up to date with what’s happening in your industry 67%
To improve the quality of the work you do 65%
To acquire a new body of knowledge or skills 63%
To increase your qualification for a desired job 34%
To become compliant to industry standards 30%
To learn to do your job 29%

sec.p: Beyond COVID, there are other crises affecting our markets and our lives including the Climate Emergency and a potential AI crisis, which we’ll explore later. We have responsibilities as marketers to be aware of these crises, to discuss them, to influence them and ensure we do not cast away our markets, our marketing skills and our humanity as we need to embrace human-centred marketing. Hopefully the profound importance of this will prevail as the drive for growth establishes new markets, eventually on new planets.

We are entering a period of unprecedented change.Ray Kurzweil’s Law of Accelerating Returns, explored in Chapter 9, observed that the rate of progress during 1980-2000 was five times faster than theaverage rate of progress during the 20th century andthat another 20th-century’s worth of progresshappened between 2000 and 2014 and that another 20th-century’s worth of progress will happen by 2021. A couple of decades later, this scale of progress will happen multiple times in the same year and, even later, in less than one month. We know accelerated change is occurring; we’re just not sure exactly how it will manifest itself. Look very carefully at AI and keep a very open mind and a very creative mind about tech developments. Chapter 9 also looks at accelerated diffusion of innovations, accelerated corporate success, yet shorter cor-porate lifespans. AI, VR, AR, MR, IoT, MA Digital Transformationand much more are explored in Chapter 9, Digital innovation.

p.bold: Digital marketing excellence Waves of change

sec.p: Figure 1.3 shows the relentless waves of innovation we have seen through industrialization. These waves of innovation continue to shorten, the fifth wavestill ongoing. The sixth wave, marked by artificial intelligence and digitization across information of things (IoT), robotics and drones is already underway. Further automation of systems, predictive analytics, and data processing will all make an impact. In turn, physical goods and services will likely be digitized. The time to complete tasks could shift from hours to even seconds. At the same time, clean tech could come to the forefront. At the heart of each technological innovation is solving complex problems, and climate concerns are becoming increasingly pressing. Lower costs in solar PV and wind are also predicating efficiency advantages (Neufeld 2021).

sec.p: Of the eight billion people on the planet around 60% are connected to the Internet (Datare- portal 2021). There is still potential for growth since many countries still do not have a proper digital infrastructure. This is digital poverty and it restricts the economic growth of these coun-tries and the businesses within it. Plus digital exclusion happens in all countries since some people do not have the wealth or skills to access the web.

Meanwhile the number of connected devices, partly because of the Internet of Things (IoT,) reached 25 billion globally in 2021 (Gartner). So in addition to desktops, tablets, smartphones and smart watches, anything can connect with anything including cars, bikes, cards, golf clubs and tennis rackets as long as they have a sensor/camera, plus with a chip plus wireless connection they can connect to other devices. See Chapter 9 for more on IoT. The average number of smart devices per person is also growing (Figure 1.4).

It is interesting to note that the amount of data sharing has increased. Although we know our data is precious and should be managed very carefully, we seem to be happy to share (or give away) our personal data increasingly over the last five years (Deloitte 2020, discussed further in Chapter 2).

Amidst this radical period of accelerated change, we are witnessing new business models. Chapter 3 explores this in a lot more detail. But for now, consider carefully Tom Goodwin's observation about disruptive business models: “Uber, the world's largest taxi company, owns no vehicles. Facebook, the world's most popular media owner, creates no content. Alibaba, the most valuable retailer, has no inventory. And Airbnb, the world's largest accommodation provider, owns no real estate.” And this was written way back in 2015. The Harvard Business Review more recently revealed ten new truths in a post-COVID world. Top of the list was “Know Your Customers' Changing Post-Covid Attitudes,” which effectively meant new atti- tudinal segments (see Digital marketing insight: changing customer attitudes and segments).

p.bold: Changing power shifts from government to tech giants?

sec.p: There is a view from the UN Panel on Digital Co-operation that a major power shift is occur-ring as the size and scale of tech giants is so massive and powerful today, that perhaps inevitably governments/states are receding in importance (Slaughter 2019). We already have currencies (crypto) being created by non-governmental bodies. The major “digital ’’platforms or online services sometimes described by the acronym “FAMGA” dominate the digital world. FAMGA stands for Facebook (who own Instagram and WhatsApp), Amazon, Microsoft (which owns LinkedIn), Google (whose parent group Alphabet™ owns YouTube and controls the Android mobile phone operating system) and Apple (who control iOS). Apple, Microsoft, Amazon and Google have each reached market capitalizations (valuations) well above $1.5 trillion (Wallach 2021). Private companies have taken over the space race from governments.

Consider the market capitalization of Apple (how much the stock market thinks the com-pany is worth) is estimated at $2.1 trillion (= $2,100 billion), which is larger than the GDP of most countries (96%) in the world, a list that includes Brazil, Canada and Russia. Gross domestic product (GDP) is the total value of all goods and services produced by a country in a year. Saudi Arabia’s state-owned corporation Saudi Aramco has a market capitalization of $1. 9trillion = more than double the GDP of its home country, Saudi Arabia. So, although we are comparing different metrics (market cap v GDP), it still demonstrates the size, scale and perhaps influence of the tech giants. Table 1.1 compares the market capitalization of multiple tech giants and compares them with the annual GDP of countries (Lishchuk 2021).

p.italic: Why does this matter to digital marketers?

sec.p: These digital platforms have far more power than any previous media owners such as pub-lishers or TV channels. From a practical point of view, the majority of media spend is now online with the majority ofthis divided by what has been called the Facebook-Google duopoly. eMarketer (2019) reports that within the United States and United Kingdom more than 60% ofdigital media spend is now with Facebook and Google.This has led to increased competition on these platforms with auction-based media spend driving advertising higher. Many consider this situation and the limited tax paid by some of these companies anti-competitive, and this has led to the anti-trust investigations in the United States and Europe. Marketers needto develop the specific skills to compete effectively using these platforms. They also need to thinkcreatively about how their brand can engage without these platforms. We explain the organic and paid media options and best practices for these platforms inChapter 7.

p.bold: Digital marketing insight Customer attitudes and segments

sec.p: The Harvard Business Review (HBR) article "10 Truths about Post Covid Marketing" (Balis 2021) reveals that marketing messages must be personally relevant, aligned to an individual's situation and values as opposed to demographics (italic.e. multiple dimensions that influence buying behaviour). Top of the list, truth no.1, is this:
Old truth: marketing begins with knowing your customer.

New truth: marketing begins with knowing your customer segment. HBR refer to five new post-COVID segments/cohorts of buyers (drawn from the EY Future Consumer Index] with very different attitudes and priorities:

list.list-item: Affordability first (32% of consumers): living within their means and budget, focusing less on brands and more on product functionality
Health first (25%): protecting their health and that of their family, choosing products they trust to be safe and minimizing risks in the way that they shop
Planet first (16%): trying to minimize their impact on environment and buying brands that reflect their belief
Society first (15%): working together for the greater good, buying from organizations they find to be honest and transparent
Experience first (12%): living in the moment to make the most of life, often making them open to new products, brands, and experiences

sec.p: Segmenting customers and defining personas bring deeper insights to inform the full customer journey (which we explore in Chapter 2, Digital Marketing Customers).

This is a period of unprecedented change in the connected world. We have witnessed disrup-tive models, changing power-shifts from government to tech and observed changing customer attitudes and segments. To compete, marketers must understand the dominant FAMGA plat-forms and use creativity to gain cut-through.

sec.title: 1.2 PURPOSE-DRIVEN MARKETING
sec.p: We asked the question “why digital marketing”? The only viable answer to compete is “to help customers” since happy customers= sales and profits = happy shareholders. Look at Amazon - the most customer-centric company in the world. The next, even bigger question is “what isyour mission”? Google’s mission statement: “to organize the world’s information and make it universally accessible and useful” makes a lot of sense. Your mission is your raison d’etre (the reason your organization exists}. “This must include how you make the world a better place - how you ultimately help customersand stakeholders. It should also demonstrate someCSR(Corporate Social Responsibility} while giving strategic direction for the organization” (Smith 2021}.
Then you have the crunch question: “does your mission statement make your staff feel good about coming to work? Are they even aware of the missionstatement?”

p.bold: Digital marketing excellence A man on the moon

sec.p: When John F. Kennedy visited NASA, he met a janitor and asked him what he did. The janitor said: "I'm helping to put a man on the moon." A strong mission delivers a greater shared sense of purpose for all staff (Smith 2022).
All staff and all stakeholders should feel a sense of purpose from your mission statement.

Your mission statement also helps you later, whenyou develop your strategy and specifically when you choose your positioning (how you want people to perceive you - see Chapter 10). Check that your positioning is something (1} your customers want (2} you candeliver and (3} better than your competitors. A goodmission motivates your staff. It creates a real sense of purpose.
Digital marketing excellence Start with why

A sense of purpose is important, partly because customers like to buy brands that stand for somethingand partly because staff like to work for an organization that stands for something more than just making money. Something deeper. Find your sense of purpose-your passion.

“You simply cannot drive sustained performance and high levels of achievement in one’s job and careerwithout being fully engaged and feeling a strong sense of purpose.The common element that often is the spark plug for change and progress is a sense of purpose”(Moore 2017).
World-class companies profit from passion and purpose. These are “Firms of Endearment” that “endear” themselves to customers and communities.

tr.td: In ten years S&P 500 grew by 122%

sec.p: Sisodia 2014
"If you don't stand for something you're dead; it's just a question of when" (Sisodia 2014).
Simon Sinek's Golden Circle is a catalyst for change and empahises the importance of 'purpose'.

The Golden Circle theory explains how leaders caninspire cooperation, trust and change in a business based on his research into how the most successful organizations think, act and communicate if they "Start with why," italic.e. they define their purpose.

Sinek explains that " 'Why' is probably the most important message that an organization or individual can agree to communicate as this is what inspires others to action." 'Why' is how you explain your purpose and the reason you exist and behave as you do. Sinek's theory is that successfully communicating that the passion behind the 'why' is a way to communicate with the listener's limbic brain. This is thepart of our anatomy that processes feelings such as trust and loyalty - as well as decision-making. Communicating your 'why' is the basis of astrong value proposition that will differentiate your brand from others.

sec.p:
Purpose-driven companies witness higher market share gains and grow three times faster on average than their competitors, all while achieving higher workforce and customer satisfaction.</p.
Today’s consumers often identify with a brand’s purpose, seeking to connect at a deeper level even as the brand reciprocally aligns with who they are and who they want to be.
It is an organization’s soul and identity, providing both a platform to build upon and a mirror to reflect its existence in the world. It articulates why an organization exists, what problems it is here to solve, and who it wants to be to each human it touches through its work . . . businesses are using purpose to create deeper connections with consumers, do more for the communities with which they work, attract and retain talent, and in the process, are achieving greater results and impact.
Deloitte Insight (O’Brien et al 2019)
The emergence of stakeholder capitalism and stakeholder marketing
John Elkington introduced the triple bottom line (TBL) of people, planet and profit in 1993. Since then it has gained traction as shown in Figure 1.6. Kofi Annan commissioned the landmark study “Who Cares Wins” in 2005, which led to environmental, social and governance (ESG), which help responsible investors to integrate ESG factors when choosing where to invest. There are 1,000+ ESG indexes, reflecting investors’ growing appetite for ESG products. There is also a need to rigorously measure the fulfilment of objectives promised to sustainable investors. Principles for responsible investment (PERI) was launched in 2006 at the New York Stock Exchange (with 1,600 members representing over $70 trillion assets). In 2007 B Corps emerged (they consider social and environmental alongside financial returns). Then Larry Fink, CEO of Blackrock, who oversees $6 trillion of investment, said “Purpose is not the sole pursuit of profits but the animating force for achieving them.” The Business Roundtable (USA) 181 CEOs signed this new statement of purpose in 2019 “Businesses should be run for the benefit of all stakeholders” (Note: this rejected the previous dogma: “Firms should primarily serve shareholders”). This was followed by the chairman of the World Economic Forum, Klaus Schwab, announcing stakeholder capitalism in 2019: “We should seize this moment to ensure that stakeholder capitalism remains the new dominant model” (Klaus 2019). Although stakeholder capitalism was first launched by Adolf Berle and Gardiner Means in the 1932 management classic, The Modern Corporation, we would like to acknowledge the term stakeholder marketing.
FIGURE 1.6 The evolution of stakeholder capitalism.
Avoid "purpose wash" and "green wash"
Some coffee companies want to build communities, but don’t pay tax. Some oil companies talk about a sustainable future but still produce fossil fuels and invest millions to lobby against environmental protection laws.
Note: digital activities have a significant impact on energy usage. Be ready for the next wave of green issues emerging from digital usage. Digital marketing excellence COVID accelerates purposeful brands and businesses
Brands are playing an ever more active role in society today, but if many are to thrive over the next five to ten years, " 'purpose' has to be embedded at the very heart of business and culture."
Doing good is good business and social purpose drives sales. In what has been a tough year for consumers because of the Coronavirus pandemic, a brand's purpose has taken centre stage. Consumers are buying from businesses that show empathy and long-term commitment to issues that matter to them. And brands are realizing that authenticity and trust are fundamental in driving these connections with consumers.
"Prior to the pandemic there was this movement towards wanting sustainable, accessible and inclusive products, but this has all accelerated," said MJ DePalma, head of inclusive marketing for Microsoft Advertising.M Baker 2020
Once again, the COVID pandemic has driven a change in attitudes, to the extent that American writer Mark Schaefer created his own manifesto for human-centred marketing (Figure 1.7).
FIGURE 1.7 > A manifesto for human-centred marketing. Source: Schaefer (2019). Reproduced by kind permission of Mark Schaefer
Volvo share safety belt patent with competitors
Some visionary companies like Volvo embraced stakeholder marketing principles back in the 1950s. Volvo gave away the patent for, arguably, its most important invention: the life-saving three-point seat belt, because Volvo felt it was “too significant not to share.”
Estimates suggest up to 1 million lives have been saved because of the three-point safety belt. Invented in 1959 and eventually installed in all Volvo cars in 1963, Volvo opened up the patent to help any car manufacturer to use it. “The invention was so significant, it had more value as a free life-saving tool than something to profit from” (England 2013).
Volvo’s managing director Alan Dessell is quoted as saying: “The decision to release the three-point seat belt patent was visionary and in line with Volvo’s guiding principle of safety” (Clarke 2013).
Every car manufactured today uses three-point seat belts . . . and it all started with a Volvo PV544 delivered to a dealership in the town of Kristianstad, Sweden (England 2013).
Relentlessly relevant brands Today’s customers are ruthless at ignoring the tens of thousands of brands that don’t interest them. But for their favourites, they welcome with open arms new approaches. These brand favourites continuously focus on loyalty and re-earning that loyalty. They do something other brands don’t: they relentlessly pursue new ways to connect with, engage and excite their customers (see Coca-Cola in this chapter). Scott Davis (2020) suggests that they use four factors:
(1) customer obsession; (2) ruthless pragmatism (they try new ideas, fail fast, experiment, are always available where ever customers have the need, have great CX and constantly make life easier for theircustomers); (3) pervasive innovation (make emotionalconnections, earn trust and often exist to fulfil a larger purpose); (4) distinctive inspiration (engagewith customers in new and creative ways and find newways to address unmet needs). Did you notice that these excellent companies “earn trust and oftenexist to fulfil a larger purpose”? Purpose combined with passion is a powerful combination that leads to success. There is a lot more on purpose and passion in the Actions section in Chapter 10 (Digital marketing plan).
Responsible AI
As mentioned at the beginning of this chapter, the pace of technical advances is accelerating, nowhere more so than Artificial Intelligence (AI) as we will see from examples throughout this book and, in particular, Chapter 9, Digital innovation. AI is already adding value to customer experiences, developing new products, setting prices, improving customer communications and much more. As AI continuously and rapidly improves, you need to ask that same question: “how does this help my customer?” Some of the time it will be all about improving efficiencies and effectiveness, and other times it will be surprisingly creative, like finding new product ideas and creating communications (conversations, headlines, copy, artwork) all potentially personalized and so relevant to each individual customer that it may first seem wonderful.
Can AI be used immorally?
We have already seen the abuse of data by Cambridge Analytica and subsequent illegal ads being used in US election campaigns and the BREXIT campaign in the UK. The debate rolls on regarding data usage. Some businesses have suffered “Negative SEO” where poor quality backlinks are automatically pointed to their site, although Google has developed filters to try to identify this, moving on to trolls who can track relevant conversations, view profiles and post personalized inflammatory, rude or upsetting statements online to elicit strong emotional responses or to steer the conversation off-topic. Fuelling society with misinformation and disinformation can break down society and perhaps democracy. Trolling can be done by humans or AI-driven chatbots to influence buyers, voters or just attitudes and opinions. This can be organized by “hostile states” who are fanning extremism as a means to create a terrorist threat within a host country. Could AI-driven bots be ever used to unfairly or immorally win business or change brand attitudes?
The power of AI
Chapter 9 explores the types of AI that help marketers, AI challenges, opportunities and solu-tions in much more detail. We certainly need to be aware of the power of AI and the importance of ethical and responsible use of AI. There is, of course, an argument that Super AI could have the capability to decideto rid humanity of humanity (if it was given a briefto “stop world hunger” or “save the planet”). As technology development accelerates, new philosophical, theological and business debates will emerge. It is important to stay abreast of these developments, discussions and decisionsin the future.
One final recommendation is to read Mark O’Connell’s thought provoking article from 2017 “Your animal life is over. Machine life hasbegun.” Meanwhile, here’s Professor Klaus Schwab, founder and executive chairman of the World Economic Forum observation “There Has Never Been a Time of Greater Promise or Potential Peril” (2016).You can read the full quote in Chapter 9. In the interim, here’s how Coca Cola are using AI andfresh thinking to engage their customers and learn from them so that they too can use insights-driven marketing to boost their results.
Digital marketing insight Coca-Cola's AI
Coca-Cola markets 500 soft drinks in more than 200 countries with 80,000 employees. Converging big data from social media, mobile apps, cloud computing and e-commerce helps Coca-Cola to "relate to our customers and bolster advocacy. It leverages the data it collects from its customers across the globe" (Jarrell 2021). The 50,000 Coca-Cola Freestyle drink dispensers allow customers to select 200 sparkling and still drinks (plus combine beverages from the entire portfolio) and dispense 14 million beverages every day (Freestyle is a billion-dollar business now).
Of the beverages consumed from Freestyle dispensers, 48% are products that are outside of the conventional top ten. The data gleaned from these self-serving dispensers uncovered valuable insights about customer preferences in different locations and times of the year, which helped to develop a suite of new drinks.
They use machine learning to learn how to read accurately the numbers inside the bottle caps so they can run efficient sales promotions.
"In order to use the mobile app, consumers need to register with their social media account. Coca-Cola uses AI to analyse the social media content of their consumers, gener-ating insights on where, when and how its products are consumed."
Coca-Cola can now "create social media material that is more likely to resonate with its target demographic in various regions across the world thanks to AI image analysis, resulting in a more efficient use of marketing expenditures and, ideally, greater sales margins." Jarrell (2021)
Section 1.2 summary
Purpose-driven businesses are proving that they outperform those that don’t have a real purpose or even a mission statement. Stakeholder capitalism is here and now we are declaring it as a time when stakeholder marketing has arrived. Today’s brands need to stay relentlessly relevant. Observe the emerging importance of responsible AI.

1.3 INSIGHTS-DRIVEN MARKETING
Although many CEOs want their businesses to be data-driven, it is actually insights from data that create competitive advantage. Hence insights-driven is actually a better term to use, and its use is increasing by commentators; see for example, Forrester 2017. You can explain to her/ him that “data isn’t the challenge it’s creating insights that is the challenge.”
Forrester (2017) declared that insights are “a competitive differentiator that will make or break your long-term success.” They even went so far as to say that a digital strategy could be to: “harness digital insights to optimize product and service delivery.” We will explain later why we think strategy is more than just insights (see Strategy in Chapter 10), although we do agree that insights can and do create competitive advantage.
Some call it data-centric marketing. Regardless of what you call it, data enables companies to become data-centric and “build (or rebuild) their business into one that makes decisions based on metrics, as opposed to the feelings of top executives” (Manevich 2020). Others recommend “leveraging advanced analytics to support decisioning and reduce risk that can be run against a number of possible scenarios” (Kathy Bachmann, Analytic Partners Inc. in an interview with Paul Talbot 2020). You get the idea - making decisions based on data and insights reduces risk and improves the likelihood of success.
Data is the new oil
On May 6, 2017, the front cover of the Economist had an extraordinarily informative message. Something we kind of knew, but perhaps manyof us had not articulated it like this: “The world’s most valuable resource is no longer oil, but data.” There it was. Simple and beautiful in its clarity. massive statement that affect every person in business - and in particular, in marketing - today. Remember, data is an asset, and justlike any other asset it depreciates over time if it is not maintained (cleaned and stored securely). Assets can become liabilities if unmaintained. A building is an asset but if it is not maintained and it collapses it can killsomeone, plus its owners will be sued. Data is an asset that, if not maintained and held securely, will cause problems with customers anddata institutions.Some estimates suggest that a customer database deteriorates at the rate of 25% each year as people die,change jobs, or move countries.
FIGURE 1.8 Data is the new oil.The Economist.
Building an Insights-Driven Business with The Virtuous Circle Of Data
Ant Bank (China) - collect more data all the tim = more data = better analysis = better insights = better new products = more sales = more customers (an more customer data from same customers) = more data=more insights etc. etc.
Constantly asking questions of their data, they discovered that a disproportionate number of young women with tight jeans break their mobile phone screens . . . so they launched an insurance service for a few cents a week only to ladies with tight jeans. Ithas become yet another successful product from Ant. See more on Ant in Chapter 9.
The virtuous circle of insights-driven marketing

1.4 DIGITAL MARKETING DEFINITIONS AND ESSENTIAL CONCEPTS
As digital marketing has changed the way we do business and marketing, many new labels have been used to highlight these new opportunities. Not all labels are perhaps useful, for us “Big Data” was “Big Hype” from MarTech vendors, for example, but new marketing concepts such as inbound and lifecycle marketing are useful to help your colleagues or clients understand potential improvements to communications.
Digital marketing and e-commerce definitions
Since there are many terms or jargon used in digital marketing today let us briefly define and clarify a few terms that can cause some confusion and somethat highlight trends such as sub-scription and conversational commerce. We highlight new terms we introduce in bold that are listed in the Glossary.
Marketing (online and offline) has been usefully defined as the management discipline responsible fo “identifying, anticipating and satisfying customer requirements profitably.” This Chartered Institute of Marketing (CIM) definition looks not only at identifying customer needs but also satisfying them (short-term) and anticipating them in the future (long-term retention). We would also consider changing “profitably” for “efficiently” in any definition to allow for not- for-profit organizations.
Digital marketing has the same responsibilities of identifying, anticipating and satisfying customer requirements efficiently - through the use of digital (or online) tools and techniques. Soon “Digital Marketing” will be just considered as a fundamental part of marketing. Integrating digital (or online) with offline marketing is essential, so ensure you explain how digital marketing activities are integrated with other communications and aligned to marketing goals.
E-commerce refers to all electronically mediated information exchanges between an organi-zation and its external stakeholders. It often refers to purchase transactions only italic.e. online sales where a commercial transaction takes place (this includes integrated processes for showing stock availability (or service availability), placing orders, order acknowledgement, payment, data security, logistics, accounting and finance).
Subscription commerce is increasing in importance as explained in Chapter 3. This is defined as a business model that allows customers to subscribe to products or services they need on a recurring basis. A benefit is that this model can increase your customer’s lifetime value significantly.
Conversational commerce Although similar to conversational marketing, conversational commerce goes a step further than finding information and booking appointments; it completes the sale. See Chapter 9 formore detail.
Digital business (E-business) is broader than e-commerce referring to all electronically mediated information exchanges supporting the range of business processes, both within an organization and with external stakeholders and/or ecosystems. This effectively can include all digital business processes, such as sales, customer service, operations, finance, procurement, logistics and fulfilment, seamlessly integrated and automated, where possible. Since the quality of these activities will ultimately affect customer’s and stakeholder’s experience and perception of a brand, marketers are now more closelyinvolved with these activities than in the pre-digital age. For example, social listening, which we explore in Chapter 6, reviews social media to identify improvements to product and process.

Intermediaries, distribution channels and influencers all need to be managed carefully. Choos-ing which channel and channel partners to work with is part of strategy (see Chapter 10 section on Strategy). Some markets squeeze out the middleman (e.g. holiday markets and travel agents), while others are introducing a middleman e.g. “Go Compare,” a vertical website for buying insurance. Customer lifecycle marketing
Customer lifecycle marketing is an essential way of thinking for marketers. It summarizes a planned approach to scheduling and optimizing continuous always-on marketing activities that support customer acquisition and retention. These activities aim to maximize visibility and persuasion through the customer lifecycle.
Key “always-on” activities include paid and natural search marketing to increase visibility as visitors search for products, information orentertainment; social media and influence marketing to encourage recommendations. Once visitors are aware of a brand, their interest can be nurtured by marketing automation techniques to feature persuasive content marketing including email marketing, SMS messaging or push notification plus on-site personalization and off- site re-targeting ads.
We like the Smart Insights RACE marketing planning framework developed by Dave Chaffey (Smart Insights, 2010) because it goes further than attention/awareness, interest, desire and action (purchase) (AIDA)since the relationship is only really beginning (notending) when you make that first sale. Although RACE is sometimes thought of as a digital marketing planning framework, it’s designed to support multichannel (or omnichannel) marketing planning. Digital channels always work best when they are integrated with other channels so, where appropriate, digital channels should be combined with the traditional offline media and channels. The most important aspects of integration are, first, using traditional media to raise awareness of the value of the online presences at the reach and act stages and, second, at the convert and engage steps where customers will often still prefer to interact with customer representatives, and this will typically increase conversion rates, average order value and lifetime value.
Through the engage customer communications activities, RACE also emphasizes the need to manage customer retention from online customer onboarding to loyalty in a structured way. It’s the reason why American car salesmen and women were trained to sell ten cars to one individual. What does that mean? It means that each customer will probably buy at least 10 cars over the next 20-30 years. Hence, if you keep the customer happy, keep them engaged and rewarded, italic.e. keep the relationship going, it is likely that you will make many more sales during the life of that one customer. If an average price of a car is $30k then that customer is worth $300k over the next 20-30 years. Isn’t it worth keeping in touch, understanding their changing needs, being relevant and helpful all the time?

Inbound marketing
Inbound marketing is a similar concept to lifecycle marketing. However, it relates mainly to customer acquisition and lead generation whereas lifecycle marketing also covers retention marketing. It describes a buying process where the consumer is proactive in seeking out infor-mation about products to suit their needs, whereas “outbound marketing” is pushing messages out via ads and emails.
Traditional media are predominantly push media where the marketing message is broad-cast from company to customer and other stakeholders. During this process, there is limited interaction with the customer, although interaction is encouraged in some cases, such as the direct-response advert or mail-order campaign.
In digital media it is often the customer who initiates contact with a brand and who is seeking information or an experience through visiting a website or company outpost. In other words, it is a pull mechanism where it is particularly important to have good visibility in search engines when customers are entering search terms relevant to a company’s products or services. Amongst marketing professionalsthis powerful new approach to marketing is now commonly known as inbound marketing (Halligan and Shaw, 2009).
Inbound marketing is powerful since it is targetswhen they are showing the highest intent, italic.e. they are actively searching for information or products. It’s also lower since it’s mainlybased on earned and owned media such as content marketing, organic search, social media and influencer marketing, so advertising wastage is reduced. Contentand search marketing can be used to target prospectswith a defined need - they are proactive and self-selecting. But this is a weakness since marketers may have less control than in traditional communicationswhere the message is pushed out to a defined audience and can help generate awareness and demand. Paid search and social media may still be used for techniques such as demand generation for account-based marketing (B2B) and retargeting (B2C and B2B).
Permission marketing
Permission marketing is a key component of lifecycle and inbound marketing. It was intro-duced by Seth Godin in his now classic Permission Marketing (Godin 1999) - where essentially marketers seek customer consent - or permission - to email or phone or contact customers. It was written way in advance of GDPR and demonstrates how best practice integrates best ethics and best privacy regs in marketing today.
Success in today’s permission marketing requires exceptional, compelling content. To emphasize the importance of content marketing to gaining permission, encouraging sharing and ongoing engagement through websites and social media, the concepts of content marketing and content strategy have developed to describe best practice approaches. By content we refer to the combination of static content forming web pages but also dynamic rich media content that encourages interaction. Videos, podcasts, user-generated content and interactive product selectors should also be considered as content which should be refined to engage site visitors.
You can see the challenge that content strategy presents since there are so many different types of content delivered in different forms to different places on different access platforms, yet it is increasingly important to engage customers in social media. Step 6: sales rep gets an auto-alert regarding high grade prospects that deserve a follow up.
The steps required to set up a marketing automation programme:
Clearly define the stages of a sale (and after sale) e.g. visitor/prospect - lead - enquiry - customer - advocate.
Define and score digital behaviour required for each stage of a sale, e.g. opening a particular email; visiting a particular page(s); downloading a white paper.
Clarify what behaviour/score triggers what response. Agree next auto steps for customers who respond ("responders" and "non-responders").
Once this detailed process is rigorously completed, an MA programme can:
Integrate social media, direct mail/email, telemarketing and more Continually serve tailored and highly relevant web landing pages to different visitors Continually respond via dynamic web pages, dynamic emails, pop up messages Alert sales or customer service people to call customers
All this without needing assistance from the IT team. You can also set up A/B tests as part of this process to see which pages/offers/photos convert better. The original book on digital body language was written by Steven Woods (co-founder of Eloqua) back in 2009.

Digital transformation
In the early days of the Internet we recall some “snake oil salesmen” advising that Internet marketing, as it was then known, was a cheap, quick and easy way to grow a business. Thirty years later we know that, while lifecycle and inbound marketing have many benefits, most would agree they are not simple. The proliferation of digital platforms, channels and devices and constant innovation giving consumers and businesses more choice mean that many businesses have failed to adapt to take advantage of digital marketing. Digital disruption from new dot-com challenger brands, of which Amazon was one of the first, has meant that many existing businesses have lost market share to their more agile online competitors and startups. In response to these challenges many businesses have started digital transformation pro-grammes. TheSalesforce definition of digital transformation highlights the importance of inte-gration of digital activities across functions and putting customers at the heart of transformation:
Digital transformation is the process of using digital technologies to create new - or modify existing - business processes, culture, and customer experiences to meet changing business and market requirements. This reimagining of business in the digital ageis digital transformation.
It transcends traditional roles like sales, marketing, and customer service. Instead, digital transformation begins and ends with how you think about, and engage with, customers. Research by Smart Insights (Chaffey 2016) investigated the challenges of managing digital marketing:
Planning. Nearly half (48%) of businesses surveyed do not have a defined digital plan or strategy although they are active in digital marketing, while more than half (63%) also don’t have a clearly-defined integrated marketing communications strategy to align against. Organizational capabilities. Many businesses either already have introduced (27%) or were planning to introduce (35%) a digital transformation programme, although a substantial proportion (25%) of businesses don't think it's relevant for them. Integration of digital channels into marketing. The survey also asked respondents to rate the maturity of their digital marketing across the customer lifecycle on a five-point scale. The majority of businesses were in categories one to five. For example, for convert, achieving sales online and/or offline, 68% of businesses rated themselves at a maturity level of 1 or 2, while only 11% rated themselves at the higher maturity level of 4 or 5.
Given the future importance of digital marketing and new entrants who are digital disruptors, larger organizations have introduced digital transformation programmes to help manage these challenges. The approach has been discussed by many management consulting groups.
Why do you want to digitally transform? This is a useful question as it reveals which kind of thinking is being prioritized. Product oriented answers revolve around better products, more efficiencies, and competitive paranoia, while customer oriented answers will be about improving the CX or helping the customer with even better services/products.
Beware, as the sad truth is that most digital transformation programmes are failing. Chap-ter 9 explains why. See also the surprisingly high level of DT failure in the Digital marketing insight box.
Digital marketing insight Most digital transformation is failing
Since digital marketing is enabled through technology, there is a danger that adoption of digital marketing technology will be led by technology decisions. This risk is highlighted in the Harvard Business Review article "Digital Transformation Is Not About Technology." Tabrizi, et al. (2019)suggest that businesses will often: "Put the cart before the horse, focusing on a specific technology ('we need a machine-learning strategy!')rather than doing the hard work of fitting the change into the overall business strategy first. Not onlyshould they align tech investments with business goals - they should also lean more on insider knowledgethan outside consultants, acknowledge fears about job loss that those insiders may have, develop deep knowledge of how changes will affect customer experience, and use process techniques borrowed from the tech world (experimentation, prototyping, etc.) to facilitate change."
70% Digital Transformation (Projects) Do not Fulfill their Goals.
A recent survey of directors, CEOs, and senior executives found that digital transformation (DT) riskis their no. 1 concern in 2019. Yet 70% of all DT initiatives do not reach their goals. Of the $1.3 trillion that was spent on DT last year, it was estimated that $900 billion went to waste. Why do some DT efforts succeed and others fail? (HBR Tabrizi et al. 2019).
Globally, examples abound of ambitious digital transformation programs wiping out shareholder value and CEO reputations. A study by Everest Group suggests that almost 73% of enterprises failed to provide any business value whatsoever from their digital transformation initiatives (Aggarwal 2021).
Existing operations and legacy technology infrastructure pose a risk to companies that can't transform quickly enough to compete against companiesthat were "born digital," according to research conducted by North Carolina State University's Enterprise Risk Management Initiative and management consulting firm Protiviti Inc (Protiviti 2021).
Post-digital world
The term post-digital describes a business world where digital marketing is simply part of marketing. And there is no need to separate digital marketing from marketing. Perhaps Unilever got it right when their head of Comms, Keith Weed, says “we are no longer doing digital marketing, but marketing in a digital world” (Weed, 2017).
There are different schools of thought when it comes to “digital marketing.” Essentially, one school says digital cannot and should not be separated from “mainstream marketing.” As it is naturally integrated into all marketing, digital marketing should never be separate from marketing (Mark Ritson). The second school of thought suggests that some companies benefit from having a centre of digital marketing excellence feeding and supplying the main marketing team/s around the world.
In Marketing Week (2021), columnist Mark Ritson suggests that referring to a digital marketing strategy is ridiculous and says: “if I ever develop a ‘digital marketing strategy’ I clearly have no idea what I am doing. For starters, the digital prefix is inherently tactical in nature and execution.”
Then we have global corporations like 3M (who have 55,000 products, managed by 100 marketers in 27 business divisions serving both consumer and B2B markets), developing a digital marketing centre of excellence to support the marketing departments. 3M knew “Everyone knew they needed to be digital, but everyone was dabbling in it. We weren’t building subject matter expertise” (Lloyd 2017). So, they built a digital marketing centre of excellence that the 100 marketers can leverage. This specialized team of about 30 - staffed by a selection of internal team members and bolstered with external hiring to fill in the skill gaps - offers everything from SEO to digital content consultation.
We hope we demonstrate in this book that, although digital communications are tactical, prioritizing digital channels, developing a data-driven (insights-driven) business and integrating AI and digital transformation are strategic. They offer opportunities for creating strategic com-petitive advantage through new business and revenue models. Executing digital tactics such as search, content and social media marketing more effectively than competitors to gain visibility, awareness and preference for brands online requires specialized skills. Whether they are in a digital centre of excellence or integrated into a major marketing department does not seem to be critical.

Digital marketing objectives: PR Smith's 5Ss
One reason why many new businesses, in particularnew startup businesses, go horribly wrong is often because objectives are not clearly agreed upon, and companies keen to get on with it jump straight to tactical tools (such as websites, Google Ads or social media) without first agreeing on clearly defined objectives and razor-sharp strategies.?
You must be clear what you want your digital marketing to deliver. What are the objectives, apart from competitive paranoia? What are the real benefits you want? There are five broad benefits of, reasons for or objectives of digital marketing:
Grow sales (through wider distribution, promotion and sales). Add value (give customers better service online). Build relations. Get closer to customers (by tracking them, asking them questions, creating a dialogue, learning about them). Save costs (of service, promotions, sales transactions and administration) and also save time (for both you when you automate some of your marketing plus for your customers who are time poor). Enhance the brand online. Reinforce brand values in a digital world where digital can wow customers beyond just better service and into new experiences that excite customers.
We explore objectives in a lot more detail in Chapter 10. For now, we can summarize as the “5Ss” - Sell, Serve, Speak, Save and Sizzle (PR Smith). These are covered briefly in the next five sections.
